content.webTitle: Liam Charles’ no-waste recipe for carrot and parsnip cookies | The Sweet Spot

fields.headline: Liam Charles’ no-waste recipe for carrot and parsnip cookies
fields.bodyText: Yes, we are using the whole carrot and parsnip to make these compost cookies – peel and all. The earthy root veg complements the sweetness of the cookie perfectly. Check it: they’re super-tasty. Carrot and parsnip compost cookies These are best eaten the day they’re made, but will keep for up to two days in an airtight container. Prep 30 min Chill 30 min Cook 20 min Makes 15 350g plain flour 100g oats ½ tsp baking powder 2 tsp mixed spice 150g unsalted butter, softened 100g soft light brown sugar 50g runny honey 1 medium egg, beaten 2 carrots, finely grated 2 parsnips, finely grated Zest and juice of 1 orange Put the flour, oats, baking powder and mixed spice in a large bowl. In another bowl, beat the butter, sugar and honey until creamy. Beat the egg into the butter mix, then add the grated carrot and parsnip, and the orange zest and juice. Tip in the dry ingredients and mix slowly to form a dough. Line a baking tray with greaseproof paper. Flour your hands, then divide the dough into 15 balls, flattening each one into a thin disc with the palm of your hand: transfer to the tray and pop in the fridge to chill for 30 minutes. Heat the oven to 200C (180C fan)/390F/gas 6. Bake the cookies for 20 minutes, or until golden brown. Leave on the tray to cool a little and firm up, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.
